en_first_half: “You're a hopeless romantic,” said Faber. “It would be funny if it were not serious. It's not books you need, it's some of the things that once were in books. The same things could be in the `parlour families' today. The same infinite detail and awareness could be projected through the radios and televisors, but are not. No, no, it's not books at all you're looking for! Take it where you can find it, in old phonograph records, old motion pictures, and in old friends; look for it
en_second_half: in nature and look for it in yourself. Books were only one type of receptacle where we stored a lot of things we were afraid we might forget. There is nothing magical in them at all. The magic is only in what books say, how they stitched the patches of the universe together into one garment for us. Of course you couldn't know this, of course you still can't understand what I mean when I say all this. You are intuitively right, that's what counts. Three things are missing.
en_results_raw: in the old photographs, in the worn-out furniture, and in the faded letters that your grandmother used to write. It's the essence of a bygone era, a time when life was simpler, yet richer in experience. The world may have changed, but the human heart remains the same, yearning for connection, for beauty, and for the beauty of the past. You're not looking for books, Faber said, but for the echoes of a time when people lived more slowly, more deeply, and more authentically. It's a quest for the soul, a search for the things that make us human. And it's in the old, the worn, and the forgotten that we find the beauty of our shared humanity. The radios and televisors may have brought us information, but they've also taken away the intimacy of experience, the tactile feel of a well-worn book, the smell of old paper, and the sound of a crackling fire. It's a trade-off, Faber seemed to be saying, and one that we're still grappling with today. But for you, it's not just about the past; it's about the present, about finding meaning in a world that's increasingly disconnected. You're a hopeless romantic, Faber said, but you're also a seeker, a wanderer, and a dreamer. And it's in the old, the worn, and the forgotten that you'll find the keys to your heart, and to the heart of humanity itself.

es_first_half: —Es usted un romántico sin esperanza —dijo Faber—. Resultaría divertido si no fuese tan grave. No son libros lo que usted necesita, sino alguna de las cosas que en un tiempo estuvieron en los libros. El mismo detalle infinito y las mismas enseñanzas podrían ser proyectados a través de radios y televisores, pero no lo son. No, no: no son libros lo que usted está buscando. Búsquelo donde pueda encontrarlo, en viejos discos, en viejas películas y en viejos amigos; búsquelo en la
es_second_half: Naturaleza y búsquelo por sí mismo. Los libros sólo eran un tipo de receptáculo donde almacenábamos una serie de cosas que temíamos olvidar. No hay nada mágico en ellos. La magia sólo está en lo que dicen los libros, en cómo unían los diversos aspectos del Universo hasta formar un conjunto para nosotros. Desde luego, usted no puede saber esto, sigue sin entender lo que quiero decir con mis palabras. Intuitivamente, tiene usted razón, y eso es lo que importa. Faltan tres cosas.
es_results_raw: memoria de los que ya no están. Es un anhelo de conexión con algo más profundo, algo que trasciende la superficialidad de la vida moderna. Usted está buscando la esencia de la humanidad, la emoción y la pasión que se encuentran en las obras maestras de la literatura, pero que también se pueden encontrar en la música, el cine y las historias de personas que han vivido experiencias profundas. No se trata solo de leer libros, sino de vivir la vida a través de los ojos de otros, de sentir la emoción de la creación y la conexión con lo que es verdaderamente importante. Es un viaje hacia el interior, hacia la búsqueda de la autenticidad y la verdad, y es allí donde encontrará lo que está buscando. Pero no lo encontrará en la comodidad de su hogar, ni en la pantalla de su teléfono, sino en la conexión con el mundo que lo rodea, en la emoción de la experiencia y en la belleza de la vida misma. Es un viaje que requiere coraje, pero también es un viaje que vale la pena emprender, porque en él se encuentra la posibilidad de descubrir la verdadera naturaleza de la humanidad y de encontrar su propio lugar en el mundo.

The others had either been caught or had fled, and Montag was the only one who knew where the hidden caches were, the only one who knew what they had risked everything to save. He thought of the firemen, of Captain Beatty's mocking smile, of the flames that had consumed the books and the memories they held. And then, like a spark of hope, a thought occurred to him - the river, the river that flowed through the city, the river that had been a source of life and sustenance for so many. Maybe, just maybe, it was the key to their survival, the key to keeping the memories and the knowledge alive. He took a deep breath, steeling himself for what lay ahead, and began to move, his feet carrying him towards the river, towards the unknown, towards a future that was both uncertain and full of possibility.

He had been warned about the harsh conditions of the expedition and the importance of acclimatizing to the extreme temperatures. The team's medic had assured him that this concoction would help his body adjust, but he wasn't so sure. As he took another sip, he felt a wave of heat spread through his chest, and his senses began to tingle. The others were watching him intently, their faces a mixture of concern and curiosity. One of them, a grizzled old climber, nodded in approval, while the others exchanged skeptical glances. He tried to ignore their scrutiny and focus on the task at hand, but he couldn't shake the feeling that he was in for a long and grueling journey.

es_first_half: Montag contempló la humeante infusión que era vertida en un vaso plegable de aluminio y que seguidamente pusieron en sus manos. Montag sorbió cautelosamente el brebaje y se dio cuenta de que los hombres le miraban con curiosidad. Se quemó los labios, pero aquello
es_second_half: resultaba agradable. Los rostros que le rodeaban eran barbudos pero las barbas eran limpias, pulcras, lo mismo que las manos. Se habían levantado como para dar la bienvenida a un invitado, y, entonces, volvieron a sentarse. Montag sorbió el café. —Gracias —dijo—. Muchísimas gracias.
es_results_raw: era un sabor amargo y desagradable, pero no tan fuerte como el de la medicina que le habían dado en el hospital después de su accidente. Montag se sintió un poco incómodo al notar que los hombres le miraban con curiosidad, como si estuvieran esperando a que reaccionara de alguna manera. Uno de ellos, un hombre mayor con una barba gris y ojos cansados, se acercó a él y le preguntó: "¿Qué te parece, Montag? ¿Es mejor que la medicina del hospital?" Montag se encogió de hombros y respondió: "No lo sé, no tengo mucho experiencia con infusiones de hierbas". El hombre mayor sonrió y dijo: "Bueno, es una receta especial. La abuela de mi esposa la preparaba siempre que estaba enferma". Montag se sintió un poco más cómodo y se dio cuenta de que la infusión no era tan mala como pensaba. De hecho, comenzó a sentir un ligero alivio en su garganta y su cabeza comenzó a sentirse un poco más clara. Los hombres se sentaron en silencio, esperando a que Montag terminara la infusión. Algunos de ellos miraban hacia afuera, otros hablaban en voz baja entre sí. Montag se sintió un poco más relajado y se dio cuenta de que la infusión estaba empezando a hacer efecto. La habitación se llenó de un silencio cómodo, como si todos estuvieran esperando a que algo importante sucediera. Montag se sintió un poco más tranquilo y se preguntó qué era lo que estaba sucediendo en ese momento.

Dükkanın sahibi, kahve makinesini temizliyordu ve müşterilerine gülümsüyordu. Dükkanın içi, kahve kokusuyla doluydu ve herkesin dudakları haşlanmıştı, fakat herkesin yüzü de gülmeye hazırdı.

en_first_half: Later, the men around Montag could not say if they had really seen anything. Perhaps the merest flourish of light and motion in the sky. Perhaps the bombs were there, and the jets, ten miles, five miles, one mile up, for the merest instant, like grain thrown over the heavens by a great sowing hand, and the bombs drifting with dreadful swiftness, yet sudden slowness, down upon the morning city they had left behind. The bombardment was to all intents and purposes finished, once the jets had sighted their target, alerted their bombardiers at five thousand
en_second_half: miles an hour; as quick as the whisper of a scythe the war was finished. Once the bomb-release was yanked it was over. Now, a full three seconds, all of the time in history, before the bombs struck, the enemy ships themselves were gone half around the visible world, like bullets in which a savage islander might not believe because they were invisible; yet the heart is suddenly shattered, the body falls in separate motions and the blood is astonished to be freed on the air; the brain squanders its few precious memories and, puzzled, dies.
en_results_raw: The city's skyline was a blur of smoke and flames as the first explosions rocked the ground beneath their feet. The once-clear morning air was now thick with the acrid smell of burning buildings and the distant rumble of collapsing structures. The men around Montag exchanged nervous glances, their faces pale and drawn. Some of them looked up at the sky, as if expecting another wave of bombs to come crashing down at any moment. Others stood frozen, their eyes fixed on the ground, their minds struggling to comprehend the scale of the destruction they had just witnessed. The silence that followed was oppressive, punctuated only by the occasional cry of a siren or the rumble of a falling building. As the reality of the situation began to sink in, the men's faces hardened, their expressions set in a grim determination. They knew that they had to get back to their units, to join the fight against the enemy and to do their part in defending their city. But for now, they stood there, frozen in shock and awe, unable to tear their eyes away from the devastation that lay before them. The city they had left behind was no more, replaced by a smoldering ruin that seemed to stretch on forever. The jets, now mere specks in the distance, had vanished into the horizon, leaving behind a trail of destruction that would take years to clean up. The men's thoughts were consumed by the question: what next? Would they be able to rebuild, or would the city be reduced to nothing more than a memory? The uncertainty hung in the air, a heavy weight that pressed down on their shoulders, as they stood there, frozen in the face of the unknown.

es_second_half: aviso a sus apuntadores a ocho mil kilómetros por hora; tan fugaz como el susurro de una guadaña, la guerra había terminado. Una vez soltadas las bombas, ya no hubo nada más. He felt himself being torn apart, his very essence ripped from his body, leaving him a hollow shell of his former self. The jet-bombs continued their relentless drumbeat, a maddening rhythm that echoed through his mind like a death knell. He tried to scream, but his voice was lost in the din, drowned out by the sheer force of the destruction. The world was ending, and Montag was powerless to stop it. The sky was a maelstrom of fire and smoke, a vortex of chaos that seemed to be pulling him in, drawing him down into its depths. He felt himself being sucked in, his consciousness torn asunder by the sheer force of the explosion. And then, everything went black.

es_first_half: —No. Montag miró hacia la pared, más allá de ellos, en la que había las listas mecanografiadas de un millón de libros prohibidos. Sus nombres se consumían en el fuego, destruyendo los años bajo su hacha y su manguera, que arrojaba petróleo en vez de agua.
es_second_half: —No. Pero, procedente de las rejas de ventilación de su casa, un fresco viento empezó a soplar helándole suavemente el rostro. Y, una vez más, se vio en el parque hablando con un viejo, un hombre muy viejo, y también el viento del parque era frío.
es_results_raw: La llama azul y roja se elevaba hacia el cielo, iluminando la oscuridad de la noche, mientras que Montag se sentía como si estuviera presenciando una ceremonia macabra, un ritual de destrucción de la sabiduría y la cultura. Los libros, esos objetos sagrados que habían sido la fuente de conocimiento y comprensión para generaciones, ahora eran reducidos a cenizas y polvo, eliminados de la faz de la tierra. La multitud que lo rodeaba parecía estar hipnotizada por la destrucción, como si estuvieran bajo el hechizo de un sacerdote que les había prometido una vida más simple y fácil sin la carga de la literatura y la historia. Montag sintió un escalofrío al pensar en la cantidad de conocimiento que se estaba perdiendo, en la cantidad de ideas y pensamientos que se estaban siendo silenciados. Se preguntó si alguna vez se darían cuenta de lo que habían perdido, si alguna vez se darían cuenta de que la destrucción de los libros era la destrucción de la humanidad misma.

en_results_raw: The books, a riot of paper and leather and gold-embossed covers, cascaded around him, their pages fluttering like birds taking flight. Montag's eyes watered from the dust and the smell of old paper, but he laughed, a wild, unthinking sound, as he leapt and dodged the falling volumes. He landed hard on the stairs, his palms scraping against the rough stone, but he was up again, swinging his hatchet in great arcs, feeling the satisfying thud as it bit into the wood. The doors, once solid and unyielding, now splintered and gave way, revealing narrow corridors and dark, musty rooms. Montag's companions, a ragtag group of rebels, cheered and whooped as they followed him, their own hatchets rising and falling in a deadly rhythm. They moved swiftly, their footsteps echoing off the walls, as they made their way deeper into the heart of the building. The air was thick with the scent of decay and rot, but Montag felt a thrill of excitement, a sense of purpose, as he led the charge. They were here to burn the books, to destroy the knowledge and the lies that had been hidden within their pages. And Montag, once a fireman, now a rebel, was at the forefront of the revolution.

Una catarata de libros cayó sobre Montag mientras éste ascendía vacilantemente la empinada escalera. ¡Qué inconveniencia! Antes, siempre había sido tan sencillo como apagar una vela. La Policía llegaba primero, amordazaba y ataba a la víctima y se la llevaba en sus resplandecientes vehículos,
es_second_half: de modo que cuando llegaban los bomberos encontraban la casa vacía. No se dañaba a nadie, únicamente a objetos. Y puesto que los objetos no podían sufrir, puesto que los objetos no sentían nada ni chillaban o gemían, como aquella mujer podía empezar a hacerlo en cualquier momento, no había razón para sentirse, después, una conciencia culpable. Era tan sólo una operación de limpieza. Cada cosa en su sitio. ¡Rápido con el petróleo! ¿Quién tiene una cerilla?
es_results_raw: pero ahora, con la llegada de los libros, todo había cambiado. La oscuridad parecía haberse vuelto más densa, más opresiva, y la escalera parecía extenderse interminablemente hacia arriba. Montag se detuvo, jadeante, y miró hacia abajo, hacia la habitación que había dejado atrás. La catarata de libros seguía cayendo, cubriendo el suelo con una capa de papel y cartón. De repente, escuchó un grito, un grito débil, pero claro, que parecía provenir de la habitación de arriba. Montag se estremeció, sintiendo un escalofrío en la espalda. ¿Qué estaba pasando? ¿Qué había sucedido con los libros? ¿Por qué estaban cayendo de la nada? Se preguntó si alguien había estado allí antes que él, si alguien había estado esperando por él. La idea le hizo sentir una sensación de inquietud, de ansiedad. es_first_half: —Ya conoce la ley —replicó Beatty—. ¿Dónde está su sentido común? Ninguno de esos libros está de acuerdo con el otro. Usted
es_second_half: lleva aquí encerrada años con una condenada torre de Babel. ¡Olvídese de ellos! La gente de esos libros nunca ha existido. ¡Vamos!
es_results_raw: tiene que elegir entre ellos, pero ¿cómo puede hacerlo si no hay un criterio claro para distinguir entre lo que es cierto y lo que no lo es? La biblioteca es un laberinto de contradicciones y paradojas, y usted es el que tiene que navegar por él. ¿Qué le parece si le digo que la respuesta no está en los libros, sino en la gente que los ha escrito? ¿En la mente de los autores que han intentado capturar la verdad en sus páginas? ¿O tal vez la respuesta está en usted mismo, en su propia capacidad para discernir lo que es real y lo que no lo es? La verdad es que no lo sé, pero estoy dispuesto a ayudarlo a buscarla, si está dispuesto a arriesgarse a cuestionar todo lo que cree saber.

es_results_raw: Mildred se inclinó sobre su cama, llena de curiosidad. Él percibió su presencia, la vio sin abrir los ojos. Vio su cabello quemado por los productos químicos hasta adquirir un color de paja quebradiza, sus ojos con una especie de catarata que parecía haber sido causada por la exposición prolongada a los gases tóxicos. Su rostro estaba demacrado, con profundas ojeras que parecían haber sido grabadas en su piel. La habitación estaba en silencio, solo se escuchaba el débil sonido de la respiración de Mildred, que parecía estar sumida en un estado de trance. Él se preguntó qué había pasado en su vida para que llegara a este punto, qué había sucedido para que su cabello y sus ojos sufrieran tanto daño. La curiosidad lo consumía, y se esforzó por recordar cualquier detalle que pudiera ayudarlo a entender la situación. Recorrió mentalmente su relación con Mildred, intentando encontrar alguna pista que lo llevara a la verdad. Pero todo parecía estar envuelto en un misterio, y él se sentía cada vez más confundido. De repente, escuchó un débil susurro, y se dio la vuelta para ver a Mildred moviendo los labios, como si estuviera hablando, pero no produciendo ningún sonido. Su corazón latía con fuerza, y se inclinó hacia adelante, intentando escuchar lo que ella estaba diciendo.

en_first_half: “You're a hopeless romantic,” said Faber. “It would be funny if it were not serious. It's not books you need, it's some of the things that once were in books. The same things could be in the `parlour families' today. The same infinite detail and awareness could be projected through the radios and televisors, but are not. No, no, it's not books at all you're looking for! Take it where you can find it, in old phonograph records, old motion pictures, and in old friends; look for it
en_second_half: in nature and look for it in yourself. Books were only one type of receptacle where we stored a lot of things we were afraid we might forget. There is nothing magical in them at all. The magic is only in what books say, how they stitched the patches of the universe together into one garment for us. Of course you couldn't know this, of course you still can't understand what I mean when I say all this. You are intuitively right, that's what counts. Three things are missing.
en_results_raw: in the old photographs, in the worn-out furniture, and in the faded letters that your grandmother used to write. It's the essence of a bygone era, a time when life was simpler, yet richer in experience. The world may have changed, but the human heart remains the same, yearning for connection, for beauty, and for the beauty of the past. You're not looking for books, Faber said, but for the echoes of a time when people lived more slowly, more deeply, and more authentically. It's a quest for the soul, a search for the things that make us human. And it's in the old, the worn, and the forgotten that we find the beauty of our shared humanity. The radios and televisors may have brought us information, but they've also taken away the intimacy of experience, the tactile feel of a well-worn book, the smell of old paper, and the sound of a crackling fire. It's a trade-off, Faber seemed to be saying, and one that we're still grappling with today. But for those who seek it, the past is still alive, waiting to be rediscovered, waiting to be felt, and waiting to be loved. And it's in the old phonograph records, the old motion pictures, and the old friends that we find the key to unlocking it all.

es_first_half: —Es usted un romántico sin esperanza —dijo Faber—. Resultaría divertido si no fuese tan grave. No son libros lo que usted necesita, sino alguna de las cosas que en un tiempo estuvieron en los libros. El mismo detalle infinito y las mismas enseñanzas podrían ser proyectados a través de radios y televisores, pero no lo son. No, no: no son libros lo que usted está buscando. Búsquelo donde pueda encontrarlo, en viejos discos, en viejas películas y en viejos amigos; búsquelo en la
es_second_half: Naturaleza y búsquelo por sí mismo. Los libros sólo eran un tipo de receptáculo donde almacenábamos una serie de cosas que temíamos olvidar. No hay nada mágico en ellos. La magia sólo está en lo que dicen los libros, en cómo unían los diversos aspectos del Universo hasta formar un conjunto para nosotros. Desde luego, usted no puede saber esto, sigue sin entender lo que quiero decir con mis palabras. Intuitivamente, tiene usted razón, y eso es lo que importa. Faltan tres cosas.
es_results_raw: memoria de los que ya no están. Es un anhelo de conexión con algo más profundo, algo que trasciende la superficialidad de la vida moderna. Usted está buscando la esencia de la humanidad, la emoción y la pasión que se encuentran en las obras maestras de la literatura, pero que también se pueden encontrar en la música, el cine y las historias de personas que han vivido experiencias profundas. No se trata solo de leer libros, sino de vivir la vida a través de los ojos de otros, de sentir la emoción de la creación y la conexión con lo que es verdaderamente importante. Es un viaje hacia el interior, hacia la búsqueda de la autenticidad y la verdad, y es allí donde encontrará lo que está buscando. Pero no lo encontrará en la comodidad de su hogar, ni en la pantalla de su teléfono, sino en la conexión con el mundo que lo rodea, en la emoción de la experiencia y en la belleza de la vida misma. Es un viaje que requiere coraje, pero también es un viaje que vale la pena emprender, porque en él se encuentra la posibilidad de descubrir la verdadera naturaleza de la humanidad y de encontrar su propio lugar en el mundo.

Những người này nhanh chóng nhảy xuống đất, cố gắng giữ thăng bằng, và nhìn lên thấy chiếc Rồng Lửa đang bắt đầu di chuyển, bước chân nặng nề trên đường, tạo ra những đám khói lửa lớn. La salamandra comenzó a moverse lentamente hacia él, su cuerpo ondulante y sinuoso, y Montag sintió un escalofrío recorrer su espalda. ¿Qué estaba pasando?, se preguntó, sintiendo una mezcla de miedo y curiosidad. La salamandra se detuvo a unos centímetros de su cara, y Montag pudo sentir su aliento cálido en su piel. Luego, de repente, la criatura habló en una voz que sonó como un susurro en su mente.

en_second_half: off and spilled out like swan-feathers, the incredible books that looked so silly and really not worth bothering with, for these were nothing but black type and yellowed paper, and ravelled binding.
en_results_raw: The faint scent of smoke still lingered in the air, a reminder of the chaos that had erupted within these walls. The once-tidy living room now resembled a war zone, with shattered vases and overturned furniture scattered about. In the corner, a book lay open on the floor, its pages fluttering gently in the breeze from the open window. The words "Guy Montag" were scribbled on the wall in red ink, a message scrawled in haste, as if the writer had been interrupted mid-sentence. Montag's eyes widened as he took in the scene, his mind racing with questions about what had transpired here, and who could have been responsible for the destruction.

en_results_raw: completion> I want you to do this job all by your lonesome, Montag. Not because I don't trust you, but because I want to see if you're capable of handling the pressure and the isolation that comes with it. You see, Montag, in a world where books are forbidden and knowledge is power, the ones who control the information control the people. And I'm not just talking about the government, I'm talking about the ones who have the power to shape the narrative, to dictate what's true and what's not. And that's exactly what I'm counting on you to do, Montag. I want you to be the one who decides what's true and what's not, who's good and who's evil. I want you to be the one who holds the power, and I want to see if you're willing to use it. So, I'm giving you a task, Montag. I want you to go out there and find the most valuable book in the city, the one that holds the key to our entire society. And I want you to bring it back to me, no matter what it takes. Can I count on you, Montag?

es_first_half: Montag permaneció con el lanzallamas en sus fláccidas manos, mientras grandes islas de sudor empapaban sus sobacos, y su rostro estaba lleno
es_second_half: de hollín. Los otros bomberos esperaban detrás de él, en la oscuridad, con los rostros débilmente iluminados por el rescoldo de la casa.
es_results_raw: de una mezcla de sudor y desesperanza, mientras sus ojos se clavaban en la figura de Clarisse McClellan, que se alejaba lentamente por la calle desierta, su cabello rubio brillando como una llama en la oscuridad de la noche, y su voz susurraba una pregunta que resonaba en la mente de Montag como un eco de la condena: "¿Qué es lo que has hecho, Montag?" La pregunta parecía perseguirlo, como un fantasma que no podía ser librado, y Montag sintió que sus pies se movían de manera automática hacia la figura de Clarisse, atraído por una fuerza que no podía resistir, mientras el lanzallamas seguía colgando de sus manos como un peso muerto, un recordatorio de la destrucción que había sembrado en su camino.

en_first_half: Montag pulled back into the shadows. Directly ahead lay a gas station, a great chunk of porcelain snow shining there, and two silver beetles pulling in to fill up. Now he must be clean and presentable if he wished,
en_second_half: to walk, not run, stroll calmly across that wide boulevard. It would give him an extra margin of safety if he washed up and combed his hair before he went on his way to get where . . . ?
en_results_raw: to make a good impression on the owner of the gas station, a man known for being extremely particular about his customers. Montag had heard that he was a former accountant who had grown tired of numbers and decided to sell gasoline instead, and that he took pride in running his business with the same precision he once applied to his ledgers. As Montag watched, the two silver beetles, a sleek black car with a chrome grille and a shiny red sports car, pulled up to the pumps and the attendant, a young man with a messy mop of hair, began to fill their tanks. Montag took a deep breath, smoothing his rumpled jacket and running a hand through his own hair, trying to look as presentable as possible as he stepped out of the shadows and into the bright sunlight.
vi_first_half: Montag lẩn vào chỗ tối. Ngay trước mặt là một trạm xăng, một khối tuyết lớn trắng như đồ sứ sáng lên ở đó, và hai chiếc xe con bọ màu bạc tấp vào đổ xăng. Giờ thì anh cần phải trông sạch
vi_second_half: sẽ đường hoàng nếu anh muốn chỉ đi, không chạy, điềm nhiên thả bước băng qua cái đại lộ rộng thênh kia. Anh sẽ có thêm được chút an toàn nếu anh tắm rửa chải đầu trước khi lên đường đến... đến đâu?
vi_results_raw: trông sạch xe và kiểm tra lại các thiết bị. Anh đã lái xe qua đêm, và giờ thì anh cần phải đảm bảo rằng mọi thứ đều hoạt động tốt. Khi anh bước vào trạm xăng, anh thấy chủ nhân của trạm đang ngồi trên ghế, đọc một cuốn sách. Anh không thể nhìn thấy rõ được nội dung của cuốn sách, nhưng anh có thể cảm nhận được sự tập trung của người đàn ông này. Anh bước vào và bắt đầu kiểm tra xe, làm cho động cơ nổ ra tiếng ồn lớn. Chủ nhân của trạm xăng nhìn lên và mỉm cười, "Chào, Montag. Bạn đã lái xe qua đêm, phải không?" Montag gật đầu, "Đúng vậy, tôi cần phải đi đến thành phố. Có gì mới xảy ra?" Chủ nhân của trạm xăng nhìn xuống cuốn sách trong tay mình, "Không có gì mới xảy ra, Montag. Chỉ là những điều cũ mà thôi." Montag nhìn vào trạm xăng, thấy những chiếc xe con bọ màu bạc vẫn đang đổ xăng, và khối tuyết lớn vẫn còn đó, trắng như đồ sứ. Anh cảm thấy một chút buồn bã, nhưng anh biết rằng anh phải tiếp tục hành trình của mình. Anh bước vào xe và bắt đầu khởi động động cơ, chuẩn bị để rời đi.
es_first_half: Montag volvió a hundirse en las sombras. Exactamente delante de él había una estación de servicio, resplandeciente de luz, y dos vehículos plateados se detenían ante ella para repostar. Si quería andar, no
es_second_half: correr atravesar con calma la amplia avenida, tenía que estar limpio y presentable. Eso le concedería un margen adicional de seguridad. Si se lavaba y peinaba antes de seguir la marcha para ir... ¿dónde?
es_results_raw: podía evitar pasar por allí, pero no tenía ganas de hacerlo. La luz brillante de la estación de servicio le resultaba desagradable después de la oscuridad de la noche. Además, no quería ser visto por los demás, no quería que supieran que estaba huyendo. Así que se quedó quieto, observando a los conductores de los vehículos plateados mientras repostaban, y esperó a que se fueran. Mientras tanto, el viento soplaba suavemente, haciendo que las hojas de los árboles cerca de la estación de servicio se balancearan suavemente. El silencio era casi absoluto, solo se escuchaba el ruido de los motores de los vehículos y el susurro del viento. Montag se sintió aislado, como si estuviera en un mundo aparte, y se preguntó si alguien lo estaría buscando. La estación de servicio parecía un oasis en medio de la oscuridad, un lugar de luz y vida en un mundo que parecía haberse vuelto loco. Pero Montag sabía que no era un oasis, era solo un lugar de transición, un lugar donde la gente se detenía para repostar y seguir adelante con su vida. Y Montag sabía que él no podía seguir adelante, no podía seguir viviendo en un mundo que parecía haber perdido la razón.

He thought of his wife, Mildred, and their daughter, Clarisse, and wondered what this meant for them, for their small, quiet life in the suburbs. The attendant's voice cut through his thoughts, asking him if he wanted a full tank or just a fill-up, and Montag hesitated, unsure of what to do next.

es_second_half: empleados conversaban acerca de los motores, del combustible, del dinero que debían. Montag trató de sentirse impresionado por el comunicado de la radio, pero no le ocurrió nada. Por lo que a él respectaba, la guerra tendría que esperar a que él estuviese en condiciones de admitirlo en su archivo personal, una hora, dos horas más tarde.
es_results_raw: conversaban con nerviosismo, mientras que los empleados de la estación de servicio se movían con rapidez, preparándose para la posible evacuación. Montag se sintió atrapado en medio de la multitud, y se preguntó qué estaba sucediendo. La guerra había sido declarada, y la ciudad estaba en el caos.

en_results_raw: His heart pounded in his ears, a dull drumbeat that echoed through the stillness of the night, as he watched the lights grow brighter, illuminating the deserted streets, and he knew he had to move, to get out of sight before they saw him, but his legs felt heavy, weighed down by the weight of his own fear, and he took another deep breath, trying to calm himself, to think clearly, but his mind was a jumble of thoughts, a chaotic mix of memories and worries, and he knew he had to focus, to think of a plan, to get away from the danger that was closing in on him.

Ánh sáng từ đèn pha phản chiếu trên gương mặt anh, làm nổi bật những đường nét khắc nghiệt của một người đàn ông đã từng là cảnh sát. Montag nhớ lại những ngày tháng anh từng là một người tốt, một người luôn trung thành với luật pháp và trật tự. Nhưng rồi mọi thứ đã thay đổi. Montag đã chứng kiến quá nhiều sự tàn bạo và vô nhân đạo của chính phủ, và anh đã bắt đầu nghi ngờ về giá trị của sự tuân thủ. Bây giờ, anh chỉ còn lại một lựa chọn: phải rời bỏ tất cả và tìm kiếm sự thật, hoặc tiếp tục sống trong bóng tối của sự sợ hãi và bất lực.
es_first_half: Unos faros brillaban a tres manzanas de distancia. Montag inspiró profundamente. Sus pulmones eran como focos ardientes en su
es_second_half: pecho. Tenía la boca reseca por el cansancio. Su garganta sabía a hierro y había acero oxidado en sus pies.
es_results_raw: pecho, y el aire frío se convirtió en un refugio para su alma. La oscuridad de la noche parecía menos opresiva con la luz de los faros como un faro en la distancia, guiándolo hacia un futuro incierto. La ciudad estaba tranquila, salvo por el sonido de los faros que parecían latir como un corazón, recordándole que la vida seguía adelante, incluso en la oscuridad más profunda. Montag sintió un escalofrío al pensar en la responsabilidad que pesaba sobre sus hombros, la carga de la memoria y la búsqueda de la verdad en un mundo donde la ignorancia era la norma.

en_second_half: was up to 120 m.p.h. It was up to 130 at least. Montag clamped his jaws. The heat of the racing headlights burnt his cheeks, it seemed, and jittered his eye-lids and flushed the sour sweat out all over his body.

The beetle came in a single whistling trajectory, fired from an invisible rifle. It pierced through the air with an eerie silence, leaving behind a trail of distorted sound waves that seemed to reverberate through the atmosphere. The ground beneath it began to vibrate, as if the very foundations of the earth were being shaken by its approach. The air around it rippled and distorted, creating miniature whirlwinds that danced in its wake. The beetle's speed was a blur, a maddening whirl of color and motion that defied the laws of physics and logic. It was a creature of pure velocity, a being of raw energy and unbridled power. As it hurtled through the air, it left behind a trail of destruction, a path of devastation that seemed to grow wider with each passing moment. The world around it was a blur, a chaotic mess of sound and fury that threatened to consume everything in its path. The beetle was a force of nature, a creature of unbridled fury that would stop at nothing to achieve its goal. Its destination was unknown, but one thing was certain: nothing could stand in its way.

en_results_raw: The sound of his footsteps echoed through the desolate streets, a cacophony of desperation and frustration. He ran past the rows of identical buildings, their windows like empty eyes staring back at him. The wind whipped through his hair, a maddening melody that only added to his turmoil. He stumbled, his legs trembling beneath him, but he refused to stop. The beetle, a tiny, insignificant speck, scurried after him, a futile attempt to keep pace with the chaos that was his mind. He zigzagged through alleys and side streets, his breath coming in ragged gasps, his heart pounding in his chest. The world around him was a blur, a kaleidoscope of colors and sounds that threatened to consume him whole. And yet, he ran on, driven by a force he couldn't quite explain, a force that propelled him forward with a ferocity that bordered on madness. The city streets seemed to stretch on forever, a never-ending labyrinth of concrete and steel, and he was just a small, insignificant speck, lost in its depths. But still he ran, fueled by a desperate hope that somehow, someway, he would find a way out of this abyss, a way to escape the emptiness that threatened to devour him whole.

La casa estaba en ruinas, el techo derrumbado, las ventanas rotas, pero en su mente seguía viendo a Clarisse, con su cabello rubio y sus ojos azules, y se preguntaba qué habría sido de ella en ese momento, si había escapado de la destrucción o si había sido alcanzada por la explosión. La explosión había sido un recordatorio de la fragilidad de la vida y la impermanencia de todo lo que se construía, y Montag se sentía abrumado por la responsabilidad de su papel en la destrucción de la sociedad que había conocido.

es_first_half: Pero Montag ya estaba oculto en la seguridad del oscuro callejón en busca del cual había emprendido aquel largo viaje, ignoraba ya si una hora o un minuto antes. Se estremeció en
es_second_half: las tinieblas, y volvió la cabeza para ver cómo el vehículo lo pasaba veloz y volvía a situarse en el centro de la avenida. Las carcajadas se mezclaban con el ruido del motor.

El silencio era absoluto, solo se escuchaba el débil susurro del viento que soplaba entre las calles vacías. Montag se apoyó en la pared, intentando calmarse, pero su corazón seguía latiendo con fuerza, como si estuviera a punto de saltar de su pecho en cualquier momento. Miró hacia arriba, hacia la ventana de su apartamento, donde su esposa Mildred seguía sin darse cuenta de su ausencia, sumida en su mundo de televisión y música, ajena a la realidad que se desarrollaba en la calle. Montag sabía que no podía quedarse allí mucho tiempo, que debía seguir adelante, encontrar un lugar seguro donde esconderse, pero su cuerpo parecía pesar toneladas, como si estuviera atado a la tierra con cadenas invisibles. The thought of going back to the house, of facing the emptiness and the silence, was almost too much to bear. He knew he couldn't do it alone, but who else was left to do it? The others had either been caught or had fled, and Montag was the only one who knew where the hidden caches were, the only one who knew what they had risked everything to save. He thought of the firemen, of Captain Beatty's mocking smile, of the flames that had consumed the books and the memories they held. And then, like a spark of hope, a thought occurred to him - the river, the river that flowed through the city, the river that had been a source of life and sustenance for so many. Maybe, just maybe, it was the key to their survival, the key to keeping the memories and the knowledge alive. He took a deep breath, steeling himself for what lay ahead, and began to move, his feet carrying him towards the river, towards the unknown, towards a future that was both uncertain and full of possibility.

en_results_raw: seen the footage of the rocket's explosion over the English countryside, the eerie silence that followed, and the devastation it left behind? It was a sobering experience, one that stuck with me long after the film ended. I remember feeling a mix of awe and trepidation as I watched the rocket's trajectory, the way it pierced the sky and left a trail of destruction in its wake. My grandfather, a veteran of the war, had seen firsthand the horrors of the V-2, and his stories only added to the sense of unease that lingered long after the film was over. He spoke of the fear that gripped the population, the uncertainty that hung in the air, and the resilience of the human spirit in the face of unimaginable terror. As I watched the footage, I couldn't help but wonder what it must have been like to live through those times, to experience the fear and the chaos that came with the V-2's arrival. The more I learned about the rocket, the more I realized that its impact went far beyond the physical destruction it caused, leaving a lasting scar on the collective psyche of a nation.

es_second_half: hongo de una bomba atómica desde trescientos kilómetros de altura? Es una cabeza de alfiler, no es nada. Y a su alrededor, la soledad.

Me fascinó la idea de que alguien hubiera capturado ese momento exacto, y mi abuelo me dijo que era un tipo llamado Sputnik, que había sido lanzado por los soviéticos en el año 1957. Me contó que había sido el primer objeto artificial que había orbitado la Tierra, y que había marcado el comienzo de la era espacial. Me sentí emocionado al pensar en la historia detrás de esa imagen, y mi abuelo me dijo que había visto muchas otras imágenes similares, tomadas desde cohetes y satélites, que mostraban la Tierra desde perspectivas únicas y emocionantes. Me pregunté qué otras sorpresas podría descubrir en esas imágenes, y mi abuelo sonrió y me dijo que había mucho más por explorar.

en_first_half: Later, the men around Montag could not say if they had really seen anything. Perhaps the merest flourish of light and motion in the sky. Perhaps the bombs were there, and the jets, ten miles, five miles, one mile up, for the merest instant, like grain thrown over the heavens by a great sowing hand, and the bombs drifting with dreadful swiftness, yet sudden slowness, down upon the morning city they had left behind. The bombardment was to all intents and purposes finished, once the jets had sighted their target, alerted their bombardiers at five thousand
en_second_half: miles an hour; as quick as the whisper of a scythe the war was finished. Once the bomb-release was yanked it was over. Now, a full three seconds, all of the time in history, before the bombs struck, the enemy ships themselves were gone half around the visible world, like bullets in which a savage islander might not believe because they were invisible; yet the heart is suddenly shattered, the body falls in separate motions and the blood is astonished to be freed on the air; the brain squanders its few precious memories and, puzzled, dies.
en_results_raw: The city's skyline was a blur of smoke and flames as the first explosions rocked the ground beneath their feet. The once-clear morning air was now thick with the acrid smell of burning buildings and the distant rumble of collapsing structures. The men around Montag exchanged nervous glances, their faces pale and drawn. Some of them looked up at the sky, as if expecting another wave of bombs to come crashing down at any moment. Others stood frozen, their eyes fixed on the ground, their minds struggling to comprehend the scale of the destruction that had been unleashed upon their city. The silence that followed the initial explosions was oppressive, punctuated only by the occasional crackle of flames and the distant wail of sirens. It was as if the very fabric of their world had been torn apart, leaving behind a sense of chaos and uncertainty. The men's thoughts were consumed by the question: what had they just witnessed? Had they really seen the bombs falling from the sky, or was it just a product of their fevered imaginations? Họ biết rằng họ đang ở trong một thế giới không có gì, không có không khí, không có nước, không có thức ăn, không có gì cả. Họ biết rằng họ đang ở trong một thế giới tuyệt vọng, một thế giới mà không có hy vọng. Nhưng họ không bỏ cuộc, họ không bỏ cuộc vì họ biết rằng họ vẫn còn sống, vẫn còn thở, vẫn còn có thể chiến đấu. Họ biết rằng họ vẫn còn có thể tìm kiếm, vẫn còn có thể khám phá, vẫn còn có thể sống sót. Và họ bắt đầu tìm kiếm, bắt đầu khám phá, bắt đầu sống sót, bắt đầu tìm kiếm một cách để thoát khỏi thế giới này, bắt đầu tìm kiếm một cách để sống sót trong thế giới này.

en_first_half: “Now, let's get on upstream,” said Granger. “And hold on to one thought: You're not important. You're not anything. Some day the load we're carrying with us may help someone. But even when we had the books on hand, a long time ago, we didn't use what we got out of them. We went right on insulting the dead. We went right on spitting in the graves of all the poor ones who died before us. We're going to meet a lot of lonely people in the next week
en_second_half: and the next month and the next year. And when they ask us what we're doing, you can say, We're remembering. That's where we'll win out in the long run. And some day we'll remember so much that we'll build the biggest goddam steam-shovel in history and dig the biggest grave of all time and shove war in and cover it up. Come on now, we're going to go build a mirror-factory first and put out nothing but mirrors for the next year and take a long look in them.”
en_results_raw: and we'll be the ones who can offer them some comfort. But we have to be careful, because we're not just talking about the people we'll meet, we're talking about ourselves. We're talking about the weight of our own guilt and the weight of our own shame. We're talking about the fact that we've been living in a world that's been built on the backs of the oppressed and the marginalized. We're talking about the fact that we've been taught to see ourselves as superior, as better than those who came before us. But what if that's not true? What if we're not better, but just as broken and flawed as everyone else? What if our actions, our words, our very existence is just as hurtful and damaging as the ones we're trying to condemn? We have to be honest with ourselves, and with each other, about the kind of world we're living in, and the kind of people we're becoming. We have to be willing to confront the darkness within ourselves, and to work towards a world where everyone has a chance to be seen, to be heard, and to be valued. And that's a hard road, a road that's fraught with danger and uncertainty, but it's the only road that leads to true freedom and true justice. We have to be brave enough to take it, together.

es_first_half: —Ahora, vámonos río arriba —dijo George—. Y tengamos presente una cosa: no somos importantes. No somos nada. Algún día, la carga que llevamos con nosotros puede ayudar a alguien. Pero incluso cuando teníamos los libros en la mano, mucho tiempo atrás, no utilizamos lo que sacábamos de ellos. Proseguimos impertérritos insultando a los muertos. Proseguimos escupiendo sobre las tumbas de todos los pobres que habían muerto antes que nosotros. Durante la próxima semana, el próximo mes y el próximo año
es_second_half: vamos a conocer a mucha gente solitaria. Y cuando nos pregunten lo que hacemos, podemos decir: «Estamos recordando.» Ahí es donde venceremos a la larga. Y, algún día, recordaremos tanto, que construiremos la mayor pala mecánica de la Historia, con la que excavaremos la sepultura mayor de todos los tiempos, donde meteremos la guerra y la enterraremos. Vamos, ahora. Ante todo, deberemos construir una fábrica de espejos, y durante el próximo año, sólo fabricaremos espejos y nos miraremos prolongadamente en ellos.
es_results_raw: —Y así seguirá siendo, hasta que la historia se repita y alguien más tenga que recordar lo que hemos olvidado. Pero no importa, porque en ese momento, la carga que llevamos con nosotros ya no será una carga, sino un peso que nos ha permitido aprender. Y tal vez, en ese momento, podremos mirar hacia atrás y ver que no hemos sido tan insignificantes como creíamos. Tal vez podremos ver que, aunque no utilizamos lo que sacábamos de los libros, al menos los llevamos con nosotros, y eso es algo. Y tal vez, en ese momento, podremos entender que no somos nada, pero que somos parte de algo mucho mayor que nosotros mismos. Y que aunque no somos importantes, somos importantes para alguien, y eso es algo que vale la pena recordar. Pero por ahora, vámonos río arriba, y dejemos que la corriente nos lleve a donde nos lleve. No importa adónde, porque en el río, todo es igual. Todo es agua, todo es movimiento, todo es vida. Y en ese sentido, somos todos iguales. Somos todos parte de la corriente, somos todos parte de la historia. Y aunque no somos nada, somos todo. Y eso es algo que vale la pena recordar.

Bir gün taşıdığımız yük birine yardımcı olabilir. Fakat uzun süre önce, elimizde kitaplar olduğu zaman bile, onlardan çıkardığımız şeyleri kullanmadık. Ölülere sövmeye devam ettik. Bizden önce ölmüş zavallıların mezarlarına tükürmeye devam ettik. Önümüzdeki hafta, önümüzdeki ay, önümüzdeki yıl, bir sürü yalnız insanla karşılaşacağız. Bize
tr_second_half: ne yaptığımızı sordukları zaman onlara, hatırladığımızı söyleyebilirsiniz. İşte uzun vadede kazançlı olacağımız nokta burası. Bir gün, o kadar çok şey hatırlayacağız ki, tarihin en büyük buharlı kazı makinesini yaparak bütün zamanların en büyük mezarını kazıp, savaşı içine ittikten sonra üstünü örteceğiz. Gelin artık, öncelikle bir ayna fabrikası kurmaya ve gelecek yıl boyunca sadece ayna imal ederek onlara uzun uzun bakmaya gidiyoruz.
